title: Opening address

author: Nada Lavrač, Department of Knowledge Technologies, Jožef Stefan Institute

segmentation: Dear colleagues, dear friends, dear director of yours, Steven Institute and also we have representatives from the press.
Thank you very much for coming.
It was a very quick organization of an event which maybe will turn out to be pleasant and interesting.
It is a symposium on machine learning and computational creativity and there are several reasons for.
Organizing this event.
Actually, when post rationalizing why we should do it, I realized it is 10 years of the Knowledge Technologies Department at Georgia Steven Institute, which is worth celebrating.
On the other hand, there is a book which we have written by my colleagues.
You firm Kranz, Dragon Gamberger and myself and we wrote a book.

Foundations of rule learning, which was published by Springer in 2012 at the end of the year and we promoted this book already in Zagreb at Roger Boscovich Institute and our idea is to present you a little bit about rule learning also here in Juliana.
And one of the main motivations is in to introduce a new new research area in Slovenia called computational creativity, which has not been the topic of research previously in Slovenia.

The Department, very briefly, we are about 30 people, 30 researchers, 10 students doing research in data mining, text mining, web mining ontologies, decision support systems with numerous applications in medicine, bioinformatics, public health, ecology, finance, and so forth.
And one of the outcomes of our research are also numerous monographs, edited books, conference proceedings, and at the entrance to the Institute there are.
There is an exhibition of the books of the Department of Knowledge Technologies and the majority of books comes from social jerowski remarkable Hornets and other colleagues, including myself.
So you are welcome to see the exposition of books at the entrance Hall to your ship.
Steven Institute.
So as mentioned, there wasn't one of the reasons of organizing.
This event is also the publishing of the foundations of Rule learning book, and here we have Johannes Firm grants who will start the introductory talk in the morning.
We have Dragon Gamberger who will finish the morning session and myself in the middle of the session.
It's quite substantial book of 334 pages and we are getting first.
Good feedback to the book.
About the international collaboration and funding of our Department, we had stable funding not only from the local research agency but also from European projects.
And here we are just showing the current project starting with the big project 1st and then many others.
How thick the line is represents how much money there is involved and we are very happy that in the last calls.

We were successful in ensuring funding also for computational creativity projects and there was a call by the European Commission for Computational Creativity and it is in the first time the first time that this research has been and will be funded by the Commission.
We have the ongoing project muse about which I will tell a little bit more.
We have a concerted action, pro SECO, and we're happy to have Tony Villeda, coordinator of the project with us and the funding of two new computational creativity projects will start in October.
These are the projects concrete.
Coordinated by Garant Wiggins.
Unfortunately he's not with us today and the wind project coordinated by Simon Colton, who will also be one of the presenters of the afternoon session.

We are happy to compute the amount of funding we got for this research, and initially I thought it was about 800,000, but actually now that I compute it is, it's one, 2 million insured by the Commission of Net funding for the.
Period until 2016.
So we are very happy about that, which gives us stability for the Department for the next three to four years.
So first project, which I would like to mention it is an ongoing project.
It started in 2012.
It's the muse project.
Machine understanding for interactive storytelling.
Its aim is to bring text to life by text processing an 3D interactive storytelling.
The idea is that you have an input which is text.

Of course it shouldn't be philosophical text or text with that doesn't have actors or actions, so that kind of text wouldn't be a good input, but any kind of input, like children's stories or narratives.

Or maybe medical guidelines are a good input to such a system and the idea is that you would start rendering natural language texts and then the output would be a virtual 3D World in which the user could explore, explore the text through interaction reenactment and guided game playing.
So the scenario.
Real, we are addressing two scenarios in this project.
One is the children's story, 3D animation and the other one is medical guidelines 3D animation.
So we get a medical guideline.
Which would be a normal text like that it would go through and NLP processing module.
Then we would get we would put it into a planner.
The planner would have a representation of the world state and finally we would have a 3D animated story with which the end user could interact.
So in this case it is medical guideline for a patient.
Obesity patient who would undergo an operation for obesity.
So what would be the potential impact of such project?
You take text, any kind of text, you turn it into 3D.
Well, first of all, in education we are addressing children stories as a use case, but it could be any text for children which could get animated in 3D.
Maybe for some special population of children medicine like medical guidelines, airports, everybody knows about 3D animations at airports you have to put your phone out of your pocket and so forth.
And of course, game industry, which is becoming extremely important in Europe and worldwide.
This brings us to the area of computational creativity which we are introducing in Slovenia.
Computational creativity, also known as artificial creativity, mechanical creativity or creative computation.
It is a multidisciplinary research area and it has its roots of course in artificial intelligence, but also in cognitive psychology, philosophy and finally the arts and among us.
We have one of the persons who is doing art with computational means.
It is Simon Colton who does artificial art in his work.
Actually he has a painting full the creative painter who does art mechanically.
The goal of computational creativity is just to model, simulate and replicate creativity using a computer.
Excluding behavior which we would say that if performed by a human, we would consider it being creative.
And the specific goals would be to construct a program or a computer or machine which is capable, capable of human level creativity.
Of course we would also like to better understand human creativity and to formulate algorithmic perspective on creative behavior in humans and in concrete.
This is one of the basic goals of the project.
Of course we would like to design programs that can enhance human creativity without necessarily being creative themselves.
So in this respect we have a development called Crosby developed by material sheet he produces produced a very nice system which helps humans being more creative than without that system.
That was a PhD defense yesterday and we were very happy to have that.
So in addition to what is the aim of computational creativity, we can say what computational creativity can do and what it aims to do.
So the sub areas being creative, creating automatically, creating narratives, stories, metaphors, analogies, jokes.
Neola Gism's poetry.
Maybe some of it will be presented today.
Music maybe.

Some of it will be presented today, not just music composition, but musical isation of sleep, virtual arts, artifacts and so forth, and to the special interest of the group Indiana, it is creative problem solving and the particular creative knowledge Discovery which will be the research focus of our Department.
We have some previous research on that area and it we could call it by Sociative literature mining for cross domain knowledge discovery.
So we have some work in this respect, rustling system developed at the University of novel written by Ingrid Pitt Rich, supervised by Tanya Urbancic, and buoyancy is Nick.
We have Crosby as I mentioned, developed by Majic supervised by myself and buoyancy is Nick.
Also, the topics circle which he produced proves to be useful potentially for cross domain knowledge discovery we have an approach to outlier document detection.
It turns out that outlier documents may be a seat for future discoveries when crossing different domains, and some of this will be presented today.
Afternoon bite on your buncic our approach is also that all the software we produce should be reproducible and encoded in repeatable.
Workflows and potentially this workflows would be running on the cloud and the software should run on the web browser.

I mean the user could interfere and access such workflows on the browser and there is cloud flows platform developed by Giannis grants, which allows that and we will contribute this to the computational creativity projects as well.
Other projects which I mentioned already are Pro Seco, the concerted action whose coordinator is Tony, Willie and that will be promoted by him concrete.
Concept creation technology, which is more fundamental project but also dealing with narratives creation and the wind project.
The what if machine to be presented by Simon Colton.
So this brings us to the introduction to the symposium, which has started with this opening address.
In part one, we will have the presentation of the book Foundations of Rule Learning by Johannes Film grants myself and Dragon Gamberger.
We will finish at 12.
There is lunch and you are welcome to join us for lunch in the hole.
And finally, in the afternoon we will have computational creativity by Tony Willie.
Presenting pro Seco as well as gently introducing the area of computational creativity.

Honda Toivonen who will present sleep music alization as an already developed project in this area down your bunch, who will present our past work in the area of creative knowledge discovery in cross domain, literature, mining and Simon Colton towards the What if machine?
This will close.
There will be a closing address at the end and the welcome will be by Professor Ian.
Adam Lerner teach the director of yourself, Steven Institute.
Thank you very much for coming and I hope you will enjoy the event.
